2170 /// typename for tuple value
2171 template <typename T,
2172 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::tuple_value && type_count_base<T>::value >= 2,
2173 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2174 std::string type_name(); // forward declaration
2175
2176 /// Generate type name for a wrapper or container value
2177 template <typename T,
2178 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::container_value ||
2179 classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wrapper_value,
2180 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2181 std::string type_name(); // forward declaration
2182
2183 /// Print name for single element tuple types
2184 template <typename T,
2185 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::tuple_value && type_count_base<T>::value == 1,
2186 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2187 inline std::string type_name() {
2188 return type_name<typename std::decay<typename std::tuple_element<0, T>::type>::type>();
2189 }
2190
2191 /// Empty string if the index > tuple size
2192 template <typename T, std::size_t I>
2193 inline typename std::enable_if<I == type_count_base<T>::value, std::string>::type tuple_name() {
2194 return std::string{};
2195 }
2196
2197 /// Recursively generate the tuple type name
2198 template <typename T, std::size_t I>
2199 inline typename std::enable_if<(I < type_count_base<T>::value), std::string>::type tuple_name() {
2200 auto str =
2201 std::string{type_name<typename std::decay<typename std::tuple_element<I, T>::type>::type>()} + ',' + tuple_name<T, I + 1>();
2202 if (str.back() == ',')
2203 str.pop_back();
2204 return str;
2205 }
2206
2207 /// Print type name for tuples with 2 or more elements
2208 template <typename T,
2209 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::tuple_value && type_count_base<T>::value >= 2, detail::enabler>>
2210 inline std::string type_name() {
2211 auto tname = std::string(1, '[') + tuple_name<T, 0>();
2212 tname.push_back(']');
2213 return tname;
2214 }
2215
2216 /// get the type name for a type that has a value_type member
2217 template <typename T,
2218 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::container_value ||
2219 classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wrapper_value,
2220 detail::enabler>>
2221 inline std::string type_name() {
2222 return type_name<typename T::value_type>();
2223 }
2224
2225 // Lexical cast
2226
2227 /// Convert to an unsigned integral
2228 template <typename T, enable_if_t<std::is_unsigned<T>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2229 bool integral_conversion(const std::string& input, T& output) noexcept {
2230 if (input.empty() || input.front() == '-') {
2231 return false;
2232 }
2233 char* val = nullptr;
2234 errno = 0;
2235 std::uint64_t const output_ll = std::strtoull(input.c_str(), &val, 0);
2236 if (errno == ERANGE) {
2237 return false;
2238 }
2239 output = static_cast<T>(output_ll);
2240 if (val == (input.c_str() + input.size()) && static_cast<std::uint64_t>(output) == output_ll) {
2241 return true;
2242 }
2243 val = nullptr;
2244 std::int64_t const output_sll = std::strtoll(input.c_str(), &val, 0);
2245 if (val == (input.c_str() + input.size())) {
2246 output = (output_sll < 0) ? static_cast<T>(0) : static_cast<T>(output_sll);
2247 return (static_cast<std::int64_t>(output) == output_sll);
2248 }
2249 return false;
2250 }
2251
2252 /// Convert to a signed integral
2253 template <typename T, enable_if_t<std::is_signed<T>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2254 bool integral_conversion(const std::string& input, T& output) noexcept {
2255 if (input.empty()) {
2256 return false;
2257 }
2258 char* val = nullptr;
2259 errno = 0;
2260 std::int64_t const output_ll = std::strtoll(input.c_str(), &val, 0);
2261 if (errno == ERANGE) {
2262 return false;
2263 }
2264 output = static_cast<T>(output_ll);
2265 if (val == (input.c_str() + input.size()) && static_cast<std::int64_t>(output) == output_ll) {
2266 return true;
2267 }
2268 if (input == "true") {
2269 // this is to deal with a few oddities with flags and wrapper int types
2270 output = static_cast<T>(1);
2271 return true;
2272 }
2273 return false;
2274 }
2275
2276 /// Convert a flag into an integer value typically binary flags
2277 inline std::int64_t to_flag_value(std::string val) {
2278 static const std::string trueString("true");
2279 static const std::string falseString("false");
2280 if (val == trueString) {
2281 return 1;
2282 }
2283 if (val == falseString) {
2284 return -1;
2285 }
2286 val = detail::to_lower(val);
2287 std::int64_t ret = 0;
2288 if (val.size() == 1) {
2289 if (val[0] >= '1' && val[0] <= '9') {
2290 return (static_cast<std::int64_t>(val[0]) - '0');
2291 }
2292 switch (val[0]) {
2293 case '0':
2294 case 'f':
2295 case 'n':
2296 case '-':
2297 ret = -1;
2298 break;
2299 case 't':
2300 case 'y':
2301 case '+':
2302 ret = 1;
2303 break;
2304 default:
2305 throw std::invalid_argument("unrecognized character");
2306 }
2307 return ret;
2308 }
2309 if (val == trueString || val == "on" || val == "yes" || val == "enable") {
2310 ret = 1;
2311 } else if (val == falseString || val == "off" || val == "no" || val == "disable") {
2312 ret = -1;
2313 } else {
2314 ret = std::stoll(val);
2315 }
2316 return ret;
2317 }
2318
2319 /// Integer conversion
2320 template <typename T,
2321 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::integral_value ||
2322 classify_object<T>::value == object_category::unsigned_integral,
2323 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2324 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2325 return integral_conversion(input, output);
2326 }
2327
2328 /// char values
2329 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::char_value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2330 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2331 if (input.size() == 1) {
2332 output = static_cast<T>(input[0]);
2333 return true;
2334 }
2335 return integral_conversion(input, output);
2336 }
2337
2338 /// Boolean values
2339 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::boolean_value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2340 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2341 try {
2342 auto out = to_flag_value(input);
2343 output = (out > 0);
2344 return true;
2345 } catch (const std::invalid_argument&) {
2346 return false;
2347 } catch (const std::out_of_range&) {
2348 // if the number is out of the range of a 64 bit value then it is still a number and for this purpose is still
2349 // valid all we care about the sign
2350 output = (input[0] != '-');
2351 return true;
2352 }
2353 }
2354
2355 /// Floats
2356 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::floating_point, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2357 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2358 if (input.empty()) {
2359 return false;
2360 }
2361 char* val = nullptr;
2362 auto output_ld = std::strtold(input.c_str(), &val);
2363 output = static_cast<T>(output_ld);
2364 return val == (input.c_str() + input.size());
2365 }
2366
2367 /// complex
2368 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::complex_number, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2369 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2370 using XC = typename wrapped_type<T, double>::type;
2371 XC x{0.0}, y{0.0};
2372 auto str1 = input;
2373 bool worked = false;
2374 auto nloc = str1.find_last_of("+-");
2375 if (nloc != std::string::npos && nloc > 0) {
2376 worked = lexical_cast(str1.substr(0, nloc), x);
2377 str1 = str1.substr(nloc);
2378 if (str1.back() == 'i' || str1.back() == 'j')
2379 str1.pop_back();
2380 worked = worked && lexical_cast(str1, y);
2381 } else {
2382 if (str1.back() == 'i' || str1.back() == 'j') {
2383 str1.pop_back();
2384 worked = lexical_cast(str1, y);
2385 x = XC{0};
2386 } else {
2387 worked = lexical_cast(str1, x);
2388 y = XC{0};
2389 }
2390 }
2391 if (worked) {
2392 output = T{x, y};
2393 return worked;
2394 }
2395 return from_stream(input, output);
2396 }
2397
2398 /// String and similar direct assignment
2399 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::string_assignable, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2400 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2401 output = input;
2402 return true;
2403 }
2404
2405 /// String and similar constructible and copy assignment
2406 template <typename T,
2407 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::string_constructible, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2408 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2409 output = T(input);
2410 return true;
2411 }
2412
2413 /// Wide strings
2414 template <typename T,
2415 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wstring_assignable, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2416 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2417 output = widen(input);
2418 return true;
2419 }
2420
2421 template <typename T,
2422 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wstring_constructible, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2423 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2424 output = T{widen(input)};
2425 return true;
2426 }
2427
2428 /// Enumerations
2429 template <typename T, enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::enumeration, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2430 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2431 typename std::underlying_type<T>::type val;
2432 if (!integral_conversion(input, val)) {
2433 return false;
2434 }
2435 output = static_cast<T>(val);
2436 return true;
2437 }
2438
2439 /// wrapper types
2440 template <typename T,
2441 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wrapper_value &&
2442 std::is_assignable<T&, typename T::value_type>::value,
2443 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2444 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2445 typename T::value_type val;
2446 if (lexical_cast(input, val)) {
2447 output = val;
2448 return true;
2449 }
2450 return from_stream(input, output);
2451 }
2452
2453 template <typename T,
2454 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::wrapper_value &&
2455 !std::is_assignable<T&, typename T::value_type>::value && std::is_assignable<T&, T>::value,
2456 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2457 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2458 typename T::value_type val;
2459 if (lexical_cast(input, val)) {
2460 output = T{val};
2461 return true;
2462 }
2463 return from_stream(input, output);
2464 }
2465
2466 /// Assignable from double or int
2467 template <typename T,
2468 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::number_constructible, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2469 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2470 int val = 0;
2471 if (integral_conversion(input, val)) {
2472 output = T(val);
2473 return true;
2474 }
2475
2476 double dval = 0.0;
2477 if (lexical_cast(input, dval)) {
2478 output = T{dval};
2479 return true;
2480 }
2481
2482 return from_stream(input, output);
2483 }
2484
2485 /// Assignable from int
2486 template <typename T,
2487 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::integer_constructible, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2488 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2489 int val = 0;
2490 if (integral_conversion(input, val)) {
2491 output = T(val);
2492 return true;
2493 }
2494 return from_stream(input, output);
2495 }
2496
2497 /// Assignable from double
2498 template <typename T,
2499 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::double_constructible, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2500 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2501 double val = 0.0;
2502 if (lexical_cast(input, val)) {
2503 output = T{val};
2504 return true;
2505 }
2506 return from_stream(input, output);
2507 }
2508
2509 /// Non-string convertible from an int
2510 template <typename T,
2511 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::other && std::is_assignable<T&, int>::value, detail::enabler> =
2512 detail::dummy>
2513 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2514 int val = 0;
2515 if (integral_conversion(input, val)) {
2516#ifdef _MSC_VER
2517#pragma warning(push)
2518#pragma warning(disable : 4800)
2519#endif
2520 // with Atomic<XX> this could produce a warning due to the conversion but if atomic gets here it is an old style
2521 // so will most likely still work
2522 output = val;
2523#ifdef _MSC_VER
2524#pragma warning(pop)
2525#endif
2526 return true;
2527 }
2528 // LCOV_EXCL_START
2529 // This version of cast is only used for odd cases in an older compilers the fail over
2530 // from_stream is tested elsewhere an not relevant for coverage here
2531 return from_stream(input, output);
2532 // LCOV_EXCL_STOP
2533 }
2534
2535 /// Non-string parsable by a stream
2536 template <typename T,
2537 enable_if_t<classify_object<T>::value == object_category::other && !std::is_assignable<T&, int>::value, detail::enabler> =
2538 detail::dummy>
2539 bool lexical_cast(const std::string& input, T& output) {
2540 static_assert(is_istreamable<T>::value,
2541 "option object type must have a lexical cast overload or streaming input operator(>>) defined, if it "
2542 "is convertible from another type use the add_option<T, XC>(...) with XC being the known type");
2543 return from_stream(input, output);
2544 }
2545
2546 /// Assign a value through lexical cast operations
2547 /// Strings can be empty so we need to do a little different
2548 template <typename AssignTo,
2549 typename ConvertTo,
2550 enable_if_t<std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value &&
2551 (classify_object<AssignTo>::value == object_category::string_assignable ||
2552 classify_object<AssignTo>::value == object_category::string_constructible ||
2553 classify_object<AssignTo>::value == object_category::wstring_assignable ||
2554 classify_object<AssignTo>::value == object_category::wstring_constructible),
2555 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2556 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2557 return lexical_cast(input, output);
2558 }
2559
2560 /// Assign a value through lexical cast operations
2561 template <typename AssignTo,
2562 typename ConvertTo,
2563 enable_if_t<std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value && std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, AssignTo>::value &&
2564 classify_object<AssignTo>::value != object_category::string_assignable &&
2565 classify_object<AssignTo>::value != object_category::string_constructible &&
2566 classify_object<AssignTo>::value != object_category::wstring_assignable &&
2567 classify_object<AssignTo>::value != object_category::wstring_constructible,
2568 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2569 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2570 if (input.empty()) {
2571 output = AssignTo{};
2572 return true;
2573 }
2574
2575 return lexical_cast(input, output);
2576 }
2577
2578 /// Assign a value through lexical cast operations
2579 template <typename AssignTo,
2580 typename ConvertTo,
2581 enable_if_t<std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value && !std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, AssignTo>::value &&
2582 classify_object<AssignTo>::value == object_category::wrapper_value,
2583 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2584 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2585 if (input.empty()) {
2586 typename AssignTo::value_type emptyVal{};
2587 output = emptyVal;
2588 return true;
2589 }
2590 return lexical_cast(input, output);
2591 }
2592
2593 /// Assign a value through lexical cast operations for int compatible values
2594 /// mainly for atomic operations on some compilers
2595 template <
2596 typename AssignTo,
2597 typename ConvertTo,
2598 enable_if_t<std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value && !std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, AssignTo>::value &&
2599 classify_object<AssignTo>::value != object_category::wrapper_value && std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, int>::value,
2600 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2601 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2602 if (input.empty()) {
2603 output = 0;
2604 return true;
2605 }
2606 int val{0};
2607 if (lexical_cast(input, val)) {
2608#if defined(__clang__)
2609/* on some older clang compilers */
2610#pragma clang diagnostic push
2611#pragma clang diagnostic ignored "-Wsign-conversion"
2612#endif
2613 output = val;
2614#if defined(__clang__)
2615#pragma clang diagnostic pop
2616#endif
2617 return true;
2618 }
2619 return false;
2620 }
2621
2622 /// Assign a value converted from a string in lexical cast to the output value directly
2623 template <typename AssignTo,
2624 typename ConvertTo,
2625 enable_if_t<!std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value && std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, ConvertTo&>::value,
2626 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2627 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2628 ConvertTo val{};
2629 bool parse_result = (!input.empty()) ? lexical_cast(input, val) : true;
2630 if (parse_result) {
2631 output = val;
2632 }
2633 return parse_result;
2634 }
2635
2636 /// Assign a value from a lexical cast through constructing a value and move assigning it
2637 template <typename AssignTo,
2638 typename ConvertTo,
2639 enable_if_t<!std::is_same<AssignTo, ConvertTo>::value && !std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, ConvertTo&>::value &&
2640 std::is_move_assignable<AssignTo>::value,
2641 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2642 bool lexical_assign(const std::string& input, AssignTo& output) {
2643 ConvertTo val{};
2644 bool parse_result = input.empty() ? true : lexical_cast(input, val);
2645 if (parse_result) {
2646 output = AssignTo(val); // use () form of constructor to allow some implicit conversions
2647 }
2648 return parse_result;
2649 }
2650
2651 /// primary lexical conversion operation, 1 string to 1 type of some kind
2652 template <typename AssignTo,
2653 typename ConvertTo,
2654 enable_if_t<classify_object<ConvertTo>::value <= object_category::other &&
2655 classify_object<AssignTo>::value <= object_category::wrapper_value,
2656 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2657 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2658 return lexical_assign<AssignTo, ConvertTo>(strings[0], output);
2659 }
2660
2661 /// Lexical conversion if there is only one element but the conversion type is for two, then call a two element
2662 /// constructor
2663 template <typename AssignTo,
2664 typename ConvertTo,
2665 enable_if_t<(type_count<AssignTo>::value <= 2) && expected_count<AssignTo>::value == 1 &&
2666 is_tuple_like<ConvertTo>::value && type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value == 2,
2667 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2668 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2669 // the remove const is to handle pair types coming from a container
2670 using FirstType = typename std::remove_const<typename std::tuple_element<0, ConvertTo>::type>::type;
2671 using SecondType = typename std::tuple_element<1, ConvertTo>::type;
2672 FirstType v1;
2673 SecondType v2;
2674 bool retval = lexical_assign<FirstType, FirstType>(strings[0], v1);
2675 if (strings.size() > 1) {
2676 retval = retval && lexical_assign<SecondType, SecondType>(strings[1], v2);
2677 }
2678 if (retval) {
2679 output = AssignTo{v1, v2};
2680 }
2681 return retval;
2682 }
2683
2684 /// Lexical conversion of a container types of single elements
2685 template <class AssignTo,
2686 class ConvertTo,
2687 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value &&
2688 type_count<ConvertTo>::value == 1,
2689 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2690 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2691 output.erase(output.begin(), output.end());
2692 if (strings.size() == 1 && strings[0] == "{}") {
2693 return true;
2694 }
2695 bool skip_remaining = false;
2696 if (strings.size() == 2 && strings[0] == "{}" && is_separator(strings[1])) {
2697 skip_remaining = true;
2698 }
2699 for (const auto& elem : strings) {
2700 typename AssignTo::value_type out;
2701 bool const retval = lexical_assign<typename AssignTo::value_type, typename ConvertTo::value_type>(elem, out);
2702 if (!retval) {
2703 return false;
2704 }
2705 output.insert(output.end(), std::move(out));
2706 if (skip_remaining) {
2707 break;
2708 }
2709 }
2710 return (!output.empty());
2711 }
2712
2713 /// Lexical conversion for complex types
2714 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo, enable_if_t<is_complex<ConvertTo>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2715 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2716 if (strings.size() >= 2 && !strings[1].empty()) {
2717 using XC2 = typename wrapped_type<ConvertTo, double>::type;
2718 XC2 x{0.0}, y{0.0};
2719 auto str1 = strings[1];
2720 if (str1.back() == 'i' || str1.back() == 'j') {
2721 str1.pop_back();
2722 }
2723 auto worked = lexical_cast(strings[0], x) && lexical_cast(str1, y);
2724 if (worked) {
2725 output = ConvertTo{x, y};
2726 }
2727 return worked;
2728 }
2729 return lexical_assign<AssignTo, ConvertTo>(strings[0], output);
2730 }
2731
2732 /// Conversion to a vector type using a particular single type as the conversion type
2733 template <class AssignTo,
2734 class ConvertTo,
2735 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && (expected_count<ConvertTo>::value == 1) &&
2736 (type_count<ConvertTo>::value == 1),
2737 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2738 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2739 bool retval = true;
2740 output.clear();
2741 output.reserve(strings.size());
2742 for (const auto& elem : strings) {
2743 output.emplace_back();
2744 retval = retval && lexical_assign<typename AssignTo::value_type, ConvertTo>(elem, output.back());
2745 }
2746 return (!output.empty()) && retval;
2747 }
2748
2749 // forward declaration
2750
2751 /// Lexical conversion of a container types with conversion type of two elements
2752 template <class AssignTo,
2753 class ConvertTo,
2754 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value &&
2755 type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value == 2,
2756 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2757 bool lexical_conversion(std::vector<std::string> strings, AssignTo& output);
2758
2759 /// Lexical conversion of a vector types with type_size >2 forward declaration
2760 template <
2761 class AssignTo,
2762 class ConvertTo,
2763 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value &&
2764 type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value != 2 &&
2765 ((type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 2) || (type_count<ConvertTo>::value > type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value)),
2766 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2767 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output);
2768
2769 /// Conversion for tuples
2770 template <class AssignTo,
2771 class ConvertTo,
2772 enable_if_t<is_tuple_like<AssignTo>::value && is_tuple_like<ConvertTo>::value &&
2773 (type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value != type_count<ConvertTo>::value || type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 2),
2774 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2775 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output); // forward declaration
2776
2777 /// Conversion for operations where the assigned type is some class but the conversion is a mutable container or large
2778 /// tuple
2779 template <typename AssignTo,
2780 typename ConvertTo,
2781 enable_if_t<!is_tuple_like<AssignTo>::value && !is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value &&
2782 classify_object<ConvertTo>::value != object_category::wrapper_value &&
2783 (is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value || type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 2),
2784 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2785 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2786 if (strings.size() > 1 || (!strings.empty() && !(strings.front().empty()))) {
2787 ConvertTo val;
2788 auto retval = lexical_conversion<ConvertTo, ConvertTo>(strings, val);
2789 output = AssignTo{val};
2790 return retval;
2791 }
2792 output = AssignTo{};
2793 return true;
2794 }
2795
2796 /// function template for converting tuples if the static Index is greater than the tuple size
2797 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo, std::size_t I>
2798 inline typename std::enable_if<(I >= type_count_base<AssignTo>::value), bool>::type
2799 tuple_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>&, AssignTo&) {
2800 return true;
2801 }
2802
2803 /// Conversion of a tuple element where the type size ==1 and not a mutable container
2804 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo>
2805 inline typename std::enable_if<!is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value && type_count<ConvertTo>::value == 1, bool>::type
2806 tuple_type_conversion(std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2807 auto retval = lexical_assign<AssignTo, ConvertTo>(strings[0], output);
2808 strings.erase(strings.begin());
2809 return retval;
2810 }
2811
2812 /// Conversion of a tuple element where the type size !=1 but the size is fixed and not a mutable container
2813 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo>
2814 inline typename std::enable_if<!is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value && (type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 1) &&
2815 type_count<ConvertTo>::value == type_count_min<ConvertTo>::value,
2816 bool>::type
2817 tuple_type_conversion(std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2818 auto retval = lexical_conversion<AssignTo, ConvertTo>(strings, output);
2819 strings.erase(strings.begin(), strings.begin() + type_count<ConvertTo>::value);
2820 return retval;
2821 }
2822
2823 /// Conversion of a tuple element where the type is a mutable container or a type with different min and max type sizes
2824 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo>
2825 inline typename std::enable_if<is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value ||
2826 type_count<ConvertTo>::value != type_count_min<ConvertTo>::value,
2827 bool>::type
2828 tuple_type_conversion(std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2829 std::size_t index{subtype_count_min<ConvertTo>::value};
2830 const std::size_t mx_count{subtype_count<ConvertTo>::value};
2831 const std::size_t mx{(std::min)(mx_count, strings.size() - 1)};
2832
2833 while (index < mx) {
2834 if (is_separator(strings[index])) {
2835 break;
2836 }
2837 ++index;
2838 }
2839 bool retval = lexical_conversion<AssignTo, ConvertTo>(
2840 std::vector<std::string>(strings.begin(), strings.begin() + static_cast<std::ptrdiff_t>(index)), output);
2841 if (strings.size() > index) {
2842 strings.erase(strings.begin(), strings.begin() + static_cast<std::ptrdiff_t>(index) + 1);
2843 } else {
2844 strings.clear();
2845 }
2846 return retval;
2847 }
2848
2849 /// Tuple conversion operation
2850 template <class AssignTo, class ConvertTo, std::size_t I>
2851 inline typename std::enable_if<(I < type_count_base<AssignTo>::value), bool>::type
2852 tuple_conversion(std::vector<std::string> strings, AssignTo& output) {
2853 bool retval = true;
2854 using ConvertToElement = typename std::
2855 conditional<is_tuple_like<ConvertTo>::value, typename std::tuple_element<I, ConvertTo>::type, ConvertTo>::type;
2856 if (!strings.empty()) {
2857 retval = retval && tuple_type_conversion<typename std::tuple_element<I, AssignTo>::type, ConvertToElement>(
2858 strings, std::get<I>(output));
2859 }
2860 retval = retval && tuple_conversion<AssignTo, ConvertTo, I + 1>(std::move(strings), output);
2861 return retval;
2862 }
2863
2864 /// Lexical conversion of a container types with tuple elements of size 2
2865 template <class AssignTo,
2866 class ConvertTo,
2867 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value &&
2868 type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value == 2,
2869 detail::enabler>>
2870 bool lexical_conversion(std::vector<std::string> strings, AssignTo& output) {
2871 output.clear();
2872 while (!strings.empty()) {
2873 typename std::remove_const<typename std::tuple_element<0, typename ConvertTo::value_type>::type>::type v1;
2874 typename std::tuple_element<1, typename ConvertTo::value_type>::type v2;
2875 bool retval = tuple_type_conversion<decltype(v1), decltype(v1)>(strings, v1);
2876 if (!strings.empty()) {
2877 retval = retval && tuple_type_conversion<decltype(v2), decltype(v2)>(strings, v2);
2878 }
2879 if (retval) {
2880 output.insert(output.end(), typename AssignTo::value_type{v1, v2});
2881 } else {
2882 return false;
2883 }
2884 }
2885 return (!output.empty());
2886 }
2887
2888 /// lexical conversion of tuples with type count>2 or tuples of types of some element with a type size>=2
2889 template <class AssignTo,
2890 class ConvertTo,
2891 enable_if_t<is_tuple_like<AssignTo>::value && is_tuple_like<ConvertTo>::value &&
2892 (type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value != type_count<ConvertTo>::value || type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 2),
2893 detail::enabler>>
2894 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2895 static_assert(!is_tuple_like<ConvertTo>::value || type_count_base<AssignTo>::value == type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value,
2896 "if the conversion type is defined as a tuple it must be the same size as the type you are converting to");
2897 return tuple_conversion<AssignTo, ConvertTo, 0>(strings, output);
2898 }
2899
2900 /// Lexical conversion of a vector types for everything but tuples of two elements and types of size 1
2901 template <
2902 class AssignTo,
2903 class ConvertTo,
2904 enable_if_t<is_mutable_container<AssignTo>::value && is_mutable_container<ConvertTo>::value &&
2905 type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value != 2 &&
2906 ((type_count<ConvertTo>::value > 2) || (type_count<ConvertTo>::value > type_count_base<ConvertTo>::value)),
2907 detail::enabler>>
2908 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std ::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2909 bool retval = true;
2910 output.clear();
2911 std::vector<std::string> temp;
2912 std::size_t ii{0};
2913 std::size_t icount{0};
2914 std::size_t xcm{type_count<ConvertTo>::value};
2915 auto ii_max = strings.size();
2916 while (ii < ii_max) {
2917 temp.push_back(strings[ii]);
2918 ++ii;
2919 ++icount;
2920 if (icount == xcm || is_separator(temp.back()) || ii == ii_max) {
2921 if (static_cast<int>(xcm) > type_count_min<ConvertTo>::value && is_separator(temp.back())) {
2922 temp.pop_back();
2923 }
2924 typename AssignTo::value_type temp_out;
2925 retval = retval && lexical_conversion<typename AssignTo::value_type, typename ConvertTo::value_type>(temp, temp_out);
2926 temp.clear();
2927 if (!retval) {
2928 return false;
2929 }
2930 output.insert(output.end(), std::move(temp_out));
2931 icount = 0;
2932 }
2933 }
2934 return retval;
2935 }
2936
2937 /// conversion for wrapper types
2938 template <typename AssignTo,
2939 class ConvertTo,
2940 enable_if_t<classify_object<ConvertTo>::value == object_category::wrapper_value &&
2941 std::is_assignable<ConvertTo&, ConvertTo>::value,
2942 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2943 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2944 if (strings.empty() || strings.front().empty()) {
2945 output = ConvertTo{};
2946 return true;
2947 }
2948 typename ConvertTo::value_type val;
2949 if (lexical_conversion<typename ConvertTo::value_type, typename ConvertTo::value_type>(strings, val)) {
2950 output = ConvertTo{val};
2951 return true;
2952 }
2953 return false;
2954 }
2955
2956 /// conversion for wrapper types
2957 template <typename AssignTo,
2958 class ConvertTo,
2959 enable_if_t<classify_object<ConvertTo>::value == object_category::wrapper_value &&
2960 !std::is_assignable<AssignTo&, ConvertTo>::value,
2961 detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
2962 bool lexical_conversion(const std::vector<std::string>& strings, AssignTo& output) {
2963 using ConvertType = typename ConvertTo::value_type;
2964 if (strings.empty() || strings.front().empty()) {
2965 output = ConvertType{};
2966 return true;
2967 }
2968 ConvertType val;
2969 if (lexical_conversion<typename ConvertTo::value_type, typename ConvertTo::value_type>(strings, val)) {
2970 output = val;
2971 return true;
2972 }
2973 return false;
2974 }
2975
2976 /// Sum a vector of strings
2977 inline std::string sum_string_vector(const std::vector<std::string>& values) {
2978 double val{0.0};
2979 bool fail{false};
2980 std::string output;
2981 for (const auto& arg : values) {
2982 double tv{0.0};
2983 auto comp = lexical_cast(arg, tv);
2984 if (!comp) {
2985 try {
2986 tv = static_cast<double>(detail::to_flag_value(arg));
2987 } catch (const std::exception&) {
2988 fail = true;
2989 break;
2990 }
2991 }
2992 val += tv;
2993 }
2994 if (fail) {
2995 for (const auto& arg : values) {
2996 output.append(arg);
2997 }
2998 } else {
2999 if (val <= static_cast<double>((std::numeric_limits<std::int64_t>::min)()) ||
3000 val >= static_cast<double>((std::numeric_limits<std::int64_t>::max)()) || std::ceil(val) == std::floor(val)) {
3001 output = detail::value_string(static_cast<int64_t>(val));
3002 } else {
3003 output = detail::value_string(val);
3004 }
3005 }
3006 return output;
3007 }
3008
3009 } // namespace detail
3010
3011 namespace detail {
3012
3013 // Returns false if not a short option. Otherwise, sets opt name and rest and returns true
3014 CLI11_INLINE bool split_short(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& rest);
3015
3016 // Returns false if not a long option. Otherwise, sets opt name and other side of = and returns true
3017 CLI11_INLINE bool split_long(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& value);
3018
3019 // Returns false if not a windows style option. Otherwise, sets opt name and value and returns true
3020 CLI11_INLINE bool split_windows_style(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& value);
3021
3022 // Splits a string into multiple long and short names
3023 CLI11_INLINE std::vector<std::string> split_names(std::string current);
3024
3025 /// extract default flag values either {def} or starting with a !
3026 CLI11_INLINE std::vector<std::pair<std::string, std::string>> get_default_flag_values(const std::string& str);
3027
3028 /// Get a vector of short names, one of long names, and a single name
3029 CLI11_INLINE std::tuple<std::vector<std::string>, std::vector<std::string>, std::string>
3030 get_names(const std::vector<std::string>& input);
3031
3032 } // namespace detail
3033
3034 namespace detail {
3035
3036 CLI11_INLINE bool split_short(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& rest) {
3037 if (current.size() > 1 && current[0] == '-' && valid_first_char(current[1])) {
3038 name = current.substr(1, 1);
3039 rest = current.substr(2);
3040 return true;
3041 }
3042 return false;
3043 }
3044
3045 CLI11_INLINE bool split_long(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& value) {
3046 if (current.size() > 2 && current.compare(0, 2, "--") == 0 && valid_first_char(current[2])) {
3047 auto loc = current.find_first_of('=');
3048 if (loc != std::string::npos) {
3049 name = current.substr(2, loc - 2);
3050 value = current.substr(loc + 1);
3051 } else {
3052 name = current.substr(2);
3053 value = "";
3054 }
3055 return true;
3056 }
3057 return false;
3058 }
3059
3060 CLI11_INLINE bool split_windows_style(const std::string& current, std::string& name, std::string& value) {
3061 if (current.size() > 1 && current[0] == '/' && valid_first_char(current[1])) {
3062 auto loc = current.find_first_of(':');
3063 if (loc != std::string::npos) {
3064 name = current.substr(1, loc - 1);
3065 value = current.substr(loc + 1);
3066 } else {
3067 name = current.substr(1);
3068 value = "";
3069 }
3070 return true;
3071 }
3072 return false;
3073 }
3074
3075 CLI11_INLINE std::vector<std::string> split_names(std::string current) {
3076 std::vector<std::string> output;
3077 std::size_t val = 0;
3078 while ((val = current.find(',')) != std::string::npos) {
3079 output.push_back(trim_copy(current.substr(0, val)));
3080 current = current.substr(val + 1);
3081 }
3082 output.push_back(trim_copy(current));
3083 return output;
3084 }
3085
3086 CLI11_INLINE std::vector<std::pair<std::string, std::string>> get_default_flag_values(const std::string& str) {
3087 std::vector<std::string> flags = split_names(str);
3088 flags.erase(std::remove_if(
3089 flags.begin(),
3090 flags.end(),
3091 [](const std::string& name) {
3092 return ((name.empty()) ||
3093 (!(((name.find_first_of('{') != std::string::npos) && (name.back() == '}')) || (name[0] == '!'))));
3094 }),
3095 flags.end());
3096 std::vector<std::pair<std::string, std::string>> output;
3097 output.reserve(flags.size());
3098 for (auto& flag : flags) {
3099 auto def_start = flag.find_first_of('{');
3100 std::string defval = "false";
3101 if ((def_start != std::string::npos) && (flag.back() == '}')) {
3102 defval = flag.substr(def_start + 1);
3103 defval.pop_back();
3104 flag.erase(def_start, std::string::npos); // NOLINT(readability-suspicious-call-argument)
3105 }
3106 flag.erase(0, flag.find_first_not_of("-!"));
3107 output.emplace_back(flag, defval);
3108 }
3109 return output;
3110 }
3111
3112 CLI11_INLINE std::tuple<std::vector<std::string>, std::vector<std::string>, std::string>
3113 get_names(const std::vector<std::string>& input) {
3114 std::vector<std::string> short_names;
3115 std::vector<std::string> long_names;
3116 std::string pos_name;
3117
3118 for (std::string name : input) {
3119 if (name.length() == 0) {
3120 continue;
3121 }
3122 if (name.length() > 1 && name[0] == '-' && name[1] != '-') {
3123 if (name.length() == 2 && valid_first_char(name[1]))
3124 short_names.emplace_back(1, name[1]);
3125 else
3126 throw BadNameString::OneCharName(name);
3127 } else if (name.length() > 2 && name.substr(0, 2) == "--") {
3128 name = name.substr(2);
3129 if (valid_name_string(name))
3130 long_names.push_back(name);
3131 else
3132 throw BadNameString::BadLongName(name);
3133 } else if (name == "-" || name == "--") {
3134 throw BadNameString::DashesOnly(name);
3135 } else {
3136 if (pos_name.length() > 0)
3137 throw BadNameString::MultiPositionalNames(name);
3138 pos_name = name;
3139 }
3140 }
3141
3142 return std::make_tuple(short_names, long_names, pos_name);
3143 }
3144
3145 } // namespace detail
3146
3147 class App;
3148
3149 /// Holds values to load into Options
3150 struct ConfigItem {
3151 /// This is the list of parents
3152 std::vector<std::string> parents{};
3153
3154 /// This is the name
3155 std::string name{};
3156
3157 /// Listing of inputs
3158 std::vector<std::string> inputs{};
3159
3160 /// The list of parents and name joined by "."
3161 CLI11_NODISCARD std::string fullname() const {
3162 std::vector<std::string> tmp = parents;
3163 tmp.emplace_back(name);
3164 return detail::join(tmp, ".");
3165 }
3166 };
3167
3168 /// This class provides a converter for configuration files.
3169 class Config {
3170 protected:
3171 std::vector<ConfigItem> items{};
3172
3173 public:
3174 /// Convert an app into a configuration
3175 virtual std::string to_config(const App*, bool, bool, std::string) const = 0;
3176
3177 /// Convert a configuration into an app
3178 virtual std::vector<ConfigItem> from_config(std::istream&) const = 0;
3179
3180 /// Get a flag value
3181 CLI11_NODISCARD virtual std::string to_flag(const ConfigItem& item) const {
3182 if (item.inputs.size() == 1) {
3183 return item.inputs.at(0);
3184 }
3185 if (item.inputs.empty()) {
3186 return "{}";
3187 }
3188 throw ConversionError::TooManyInputsFlag(item.fullname()); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
3189 }
3190
3191 /// Parse a config file, throw an error (ParseError:ConfigParseError or FileError) on failure
3192 CLI11_NODISCARD std::vector<ConfigItem> from_file(const std::string& name) const {
3193 std::ifstream input{name};
3194 if (!input.good())
3195 throw FileError::Missing(name);
3196
3197 return from_config(input);
3198 }
3199
3200 /// Virtual destructor
3201 virtual ~Config() = default;
3202 };
3203
3204 /// This converter works with INI/TOML files; to write INI files use ConfigINI
3205 class ConfigBase : public Config {
3206 protected:
3207 /// the character used for comments
3208 char commentChar = '#';
3209 /// the character used to start an array '\0' is a default to not use
3210 char arrayStart = '[';
3211 /// the character used to end an array '\0' is a default to not use
3212 char arrayEnd = ']';
3213 /// the character used to separate elements in an array
3214 char arraySeparator = ',';
3215 /// the character used separate the name from the value
3216 char valueDelimiter = '=';
3217 /// the character to use around strings
3218 char stringQuote = '"';
3219 /// the character to use around single characters
3220 char characterQuote = '\'';
3221 /// the maximum number of layers to allow
3222 uint8_t maximumLayers{255};
3223 /// the separator used to separator parent layers
3224 char parentSeparatorChar{'.'};
3225 /// Specify the configuration index to use for arrayed sections
3226 int16_t configIndex{-1};
3227 /// Specify the configuration section that should be used
3228 std::string configSection{};
3229
3230 public:
3231 std::string to_config(const App* /*app*/, bool default_also, bool write_description, std::string prefix) const override;
3232
3233 std::vector<ConfigItem> from_config(std::istream& input) const override;
3234 /// Specify the configuration for comment characters
3235 ConfigBase* comment(char cchar) {
3236 commentChar = cchar;
3237 return this;
3238 }
3239 /// Specify the start and end characters for an array
3240 ConfigBase* arrayBounds(char aStart, char aEnd) {
3241 arrayStart = aStart;
3242 arrayEnd = aEnd;
3243 return this;
3244 }
3245 /// Specify the delimiter character for an array
3246 ConfigBase* arrayDelimiter(char aSep) {
3247 arraySeparator = aSep;
3248 return this;
3249 }
3250 /// Specify the delimiter between a name and value
3251 ConfigBase* valueSeparator(char vSep) {
3252 valueDelimiter = vSep;
3253 return this;
3254 }
3255 /// Specify the quote characters used around strings and characters
3256 ConfigBase* quoteCharacter(char qString, char qChar) {
3257 stringQuote = qString;
3258 characterQuote = qChar;
3259 return this;
3260 }
3261 /// Specify the maximum number of parents
3262 ConfigBase* maxLayers(uint8_t layers) {
3263 maximumLayers = layers;
3264 return this;
3265 }
3266 /// Specify the separator to use for parent layers
3267 ConfigBase* parentSeparator(char sep) {
3268 parentSeparatorChar = sep;
3269 return this;
3270 }
3271 /// get a reference to the configuration section
3272 std::string& sectionRef() {
3273 return configSection;
3274 }
3275 /// get the section
3276 CLI11_NODISCARD const std::string& section() const {
3277 return configSection;
3278 }
3279 /// specify a particular section of the configuration file to use
3280 ConfigBase* section(const std::string& sectionName) {
3281 configSection = sectionName;
3282 return this;
3283 }
3284
3285 /// get a reference to the configuration index
3286 int16_t& indexRef() {
3287 return configIndex;
3288 }
3289 /// get the section index
3290 CLI11_NODISCARD int16_t index() const {
3291 return configIndex;
3292 }
3293 /// specify a particular index in the section to use (-1) for all sections to use
3294 ConfigBase* index(int16_t sectionIndex) {
3295 configIndex = sectionIndex;
3296 return this;
3297 }
3298 };
3299
3300 /// the default Config is the TOML file format
3301 using ConfigTOML = ConfigBase;
3302
3303 /// ConfigINI generates a "standard" INI compliant output
3304 class ConfigINI : public ConfigTOML {
3305 public:
3306 ConfigINI() {
3307 commentChar = ';';
3308 arrayStart = '\0';
3309 arrayEnd = '\0';
3310 arraySeparator = ' ';
3311 valueDelimiter = '=';
3312 }
3313 };
3314
3315 class Option;
3316
3317 /// @defgroup validator_group Validators
3318
3319 /// @brief Some validators that are provided
3320 ///
3321 /// These are simple `std::string(const std::string&)` validators that are useful. They return
3322 /// a string if the validation fails. A custom struct is provided, as well, with the same user
3323 /// semantics, but with the ability to provide a new type name.
3324 /// @{
3325
3326 ///
3327 class Validator {
3328 protected:
3329 /// This is the description function, if empty the description_ will be used
3330 std::function<std::string()> desc_function_{[]() {
3331 return std::string{};
3332 }};
3333
3334 /// This is the base function that is to be called.
3335 /// Returns a string error message if validation fails.
3336 std::function<std::string(std::string&)> func_{[](std::string&) {
3337 return std::string{};
3338 }};
3339 /// The name for search purposes of the Validator
3340 std::string name_{};
3341 /// A Validator will only apply to an indexed value (-1 is all elements)
3342 int application_index_ = -1;
3343 /// Enable for Validator to allow it to be disabled if need be
3344 bool active_{true};
3345 /// specify that a validator should not modify the input
3346 bool non_modifying_{false};
3347
3348 Validator(std::string validator_desc, std::function<std::string(std::string&)> func)
3349 : desc_function_([validator_desc]() {
3350 return validator_desc;
3351 })
3352 , func_(std::move(func)) {
3353 }
3354
3355 public:
3356 Validator() = default;
3357 /// Construct a Validator with just the description string
3358 explicit Validator(std::string validator_desc)
3359 : desc_function_([validator_desc]() {
3360 return validator_desc;
3361 }) {
3362 }
3363 /// Construct Validator from basic information
3364 Validator(std::function<std::string(std::string&)> op, std::string validator_desc, std::string validator_name = "")
3365 : desc_function_([validator_desc]() {
3366 return validator_desc;
3367 })
3368 , func_(std::move(op))
3369 , name_(std::move(validator_name)) {
3370 }
3371 /// Set the Validator operation function
3372 Validator& operation(std::function<std::string(std::string&)> op) {
3373 func_ = std::move(op);
3374 return *this;
3375 }
3376 /// This is the required operator for a Validator - provided to help
3377 /// users (CLI11 uses the member `func` directly)
3378 std::string operator()(std::string& str) const;
3379
3380 /// This is the required operator for a Validator - provided to help
3381 /// users (CLI11 uses the member `func` directly)
3382 std::string operator()(const std::string& str) const {
3383 std::string value = str;
3384 return (active_) ? func_(value) : std::string{};
3385 }
3386
3387 /// Specify the type string
3388 Validator& description(std::string validator_desc) {
3389 desc_function_ = [validator_desc]() {
3390 return validator_desc;
3391 };
3392 return *this;
3393 }
3394 /// Specify the type string
3395 CLI11_NODISCARD Validator description(std::string validator_desc) const;
3396
3397 /// Generate type description information for the Validator
3398 CLI11_NODISCARD std::string get_description() const {
3399 if (active_) {
3400 return desc_function_();
3401 }
3402 return std::string{};
3403 }
3404 /// Specify the type string
3405 Validator& name(std::string validator_name) {
3406 name_ = std::move(validator_name);
3407 return *this;
3408 }
3409 /// Specify the type string
3410 CLI11_NODISCARD Validator name(std::string validator_name) const {
3411 Validator newval(*this);
3412 newval.name_ = std::move(validator_name);
3413 return newval;
3414 }
3415 /// Get the name of the Validator
3416 CLI11_NODISCARD const std::string& get_name() const {
3417 return name_;
3418 }
3419 /// Specify whether the Validator is active or not
3420 Validator& active(bool active_val = true) {
3421 active_ = active_val;
3422 return *this;
3423 }
3424 /// Specify whether the Validator is active or not
3425 CLI11_NODISCARD Validator active(bool active_val = true) const {
3426 Validator newval(*this);
3427 newval.active_ = active_val;
3428 return newval;
3429 }
3430
3431 /// Specify whether the Validator can be modifying or not
3432 Validator& non_modifying(bool no_modify = true) {
3433 non_modifying_ = no_modify;
3434 return *this;
3435 }
3436 /// Specify the application index of a validator
3437 Validator& application_index(int app_index) {
3438 application_index_ = app_index;
3439 return *this;
3440 }
3441 /// Specify the application index of a validator
3442 CLI11_NODISCARD Validator application_index(int app_index) const {
3443 Validator newval(*this);
3444 newval.application_index_ = app_index;
3445 return newval;
3446 }
3447 /// Get the current value of the application index
3448 CLI11_NODISCARD int get_application_index() const {
3449 return application_index_;
3450 }
3451 /// Get a boolean if the validator is active
3452 CLI11_NODISCARD bool get_active() const {
3453 return active_;
3454 }
3455
3456 /// Get a boolean if the validator is allowed to modify the input returns true if it can modify the input
3457 CLI11_NODISCARD bool get_modifying() const {
3458 return !non_modifying_;
3459 }
3460
3461 /// Combining validators is a new validator. Type comes from left validator if function, otherwise only set if the
3462 /// same.
3463 Validator operator&(const Validator& other) const;
3464
3465 /// Combining validators is a new validator. Type comes from left validator if function, otherwise only set if the
3466 /// same.
3467 Validator operator|(const Validator& other) const;
3468
3469 /// Create a validator that fails when a given validator succeeds
3470 Validator operator!() const;
3471
3472 private:
3473 void _merge_description(const Validator& val1, const Validator& val2, const std::string& merger);
3474 };
3475
3476 /// Class wrapping some of the accessors of Validator
3477 class CustomValidator : public Validator {
3478 public:
3479 };
3480 // The implementation of the built in validators is using the Validator class;
3481 // the user is only expected to use the const (static) versions (since there's no setup).
3482 // Therefore, this is in detail.
3483 namespace detail {
3484
3485 /// CLI enumeration of different file types
3486 enum class path_type { nonexistent, file, directory };
3487
3488 /// get the type of the path from a file name
3489 CLI11_INLINE path_type check_path(const char* file) noexcept;
3490
3491 /// Check for an existing file (returns error message if check fails)
3492 class ExistingFileValidator : public Validator {
3493 public:
3494 ExistingFileValidator();
3495 };
3496
3497 /// Check for an existing directory (returns error message if check fails)
3498 class ExistingDirectoryValidator : public Validator {
3499 public:
3500 ExistingDirectoryValidator();
3501 };
3502
3503 /// Check for an existing path
3504 class ExistingPathValidator : public Validator {
3505 public:
3506 ExistingPathValidator();
3507 };
3508
3509 /// Check for an non-existing path
3510 class NonexistentPathValidator : public Validator {
3511 public:
3512 NonexistentPathValidator();
3513 };
3514
3515 /// Validate the given string is a legal ipv4 address
3516 class IPV4Validator : public Validator {
3517 public:
3518 IPV4Validator();
3519 };
3520
3521 } // namespace detail
3522
3523 // Static is not needed here, because global const implies static.
3524
3525 /// Check for existing file (returns error message if check fails)
3526 const detail::ExistingFileValidator ExistingFile;
3527
3528 /// Check for an existing directory (returns error message if check fails)
3529 const detail::ExistingDirectoryValidator ExistingDirectory;
3530
3531 /// Check for an existing path
3532 const detail::ExistingPathValidator ExistingPath;
3533
3534 /// Check for an non-existing path
3535 const detail::NonexistentPathValidator NonexistentPath;
3536
3537 /// Check for an IP4 address
3538 const detail::IPV4Validator ValidIPV4;
3539
3540 /// Validate the input as a particular type
3541 template <typename DesiredType>
3542 class TypeValidator : public Validator {
3543 public:
3544 explicit TypeValidator(const std::string& validator_name)
3545 : Validator(validator_name, [](std::string& input_string) {
3546 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3547 auto val = DesiredType();
3548 if (!lexical_cast(input_string, val)) {
3549 return std::string("Failed parsing ") + input_string + " as a " + detail::type_name<DesiredType>();
3550 }
3551 return std::string();
3552 }) {
3553 }
3554 TypeValidator()
3555 : TypeValidator(detail::type_name<DesiredType>()) {
3556 }
3557 };
3558
3559 /// Check for a number
3560 const TypeValidator<double> Number("NUMBER");
3561
3562 /// Modify a path if the file is a particular default location, can be used as Check or transform
3563 /// with the error return optionally disabled
3564 class FileOnDefaultPath : public Validator {
3565 public:
3566 explicit FileOnDefaultPath(std::string default_path, bool enableErrorReturn = true);
3567 };
3568
3569 /// Produce a range (factory). Min and max are inclusive.
3570 class Range : public Validator {
3571 public:
3572 /// This produces a range with min and max inclusive.
3573 ///
3574 /// Note that the constructor is templated, but the struct is not, so C++17 is not
3575 /// needed to provide nice syntax for Range(a,b).
3576 template <typename T>
3577 Range(T min_val, T max_val, const std::string& validator_name = std::string{})
3578 : Validator(validator_name) {
3579 if (validator_name.empty()) {
3580 std::stringstream out;
3581 out << detail::type_name<T>() << " in [" << min_val << " - " << max_val << "]";
3582 description(out.str());
3583 }
3584
3585 func_ = [min_val, max_val](std::string& input) {
3586 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3587 T val;
3588 bool const converted = lexical_cast(input, val);
3589 if ((!converted) || (val < min_val || val > max_val)) {
3590 std::stringstream out;
3591 out << "Value " << input << " not in range [";
3592 out << min_val << " - " << max_val << "]";
3593 return out.str();
3594 }
3595 return std::string{};
3596 };
3597 }
3598
3599 /// Range of one value is 0 to value
3600 template <typename T>
3601 explicit Range(T max_val, const std::string& validator_name = std::string{})
3602 : Range(static_cast<T>(0), max_val, validator_name) {
3603 }
3604 };
3605
3606 /// Check for a non negative number
3607 const Range NonNegativeNumber((std::numeric_limits<double>::max)(), "NONNEGATIVE");
3608
3609 /// Check for a positive valued number (val>0.0), <double>::min here is the smallest positive number
3610 const Range PositiveNumber((std::numeric_limits<double>::min)(), (std::numeric_limits<double>::max)(), "POSITIVE");
3611
3612 /// Produce a bounded range (factory). Min and max are inclusive.
3613 class Bound : public Validator {
3614 public:
3615 /// This bounds a value with min and max inclusive.
3616 ///
3617 /// Note that the constructor is templated, but the struct is not, so C++17 is not
3618 /// needed to provide nice syntax for Range(a,b).
3619 template <typename T>
3620 Bound(T min_val, T max_val) {
3621 std::stringstream out;
3622 out << detail::type_name<T>() << " bounded to [" << min_val << " - " << max_val << "]";
3623 description(out.str());
3624
3625 func_ = [min_val, max_val](std::string& input) {
3626 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3627 T val;
3628 bool converted = lexical_cast(input, val);
3629 if (!converted) {
3630 return std::string("Value ") + input + " could not be converted";
3631 }
3632 if (val < min_val)
3633 input = detail::to_string(min_val);
3634 else if (val > max_val)
3635 input = detail::to_string(max_val);
3636
3637 return std::string{};
3638 };
3639 }
3640
3641 /// Range of one value is 0 to value
3642 template <typename T>
3643 explicit Bound(T max_val)
3644 : Bound(static_cast<T>(0), max_val) {
3645 }
3646 };
3647
3648 namespace detail {
3649 template <typename T, enable_if_t<is_copyable_ptr<typename std::remove_reference<T>::type>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
3650 auto smart_deref(T value) -> decltype(*value) {
3651 return *value;
3652 }
3653
3654 template <typename T,
3655 enable_if_t<!is_copyable_ptr<typename std::remove_reference<T>::type>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
3656 typename std::remove_reference<T>::type& smart_deref(T& value) {
3657 return value;
3658 }
3659 /// Generate a string representation of a set
3660 template <typename T>
3661 std::string generate_set(const T& set) {
3662 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type;
3663 using iteration_type_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::value_type; // the type of the object pair
3664 std::string out(1, '{');
3665 out.append(detail::join(
3666 detail::smart_deref(set),
3667 [](const iteration_type_t& v) {
3668 return detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first(v);
3669 },
3670 ","));
3671 out.push_back('}');
3672 return out;
3673 }
3674
3675 /// Generate a string representation of a map
3676 template <typename T>
3677 std::string generate_map(const T& map, bool key_only = false) {
3678 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type;
3679 using iteration_type_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::value_type; // the type of the object pair
3680 std::string out(1, '{');
3681 out.append(detail::join(
3682 detail::smart_deref(map),
3683 [key_only](const iteration_type_t& v) {
3684 std::string res{detail::to_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first(v))};
3685
3686 if (!key_only) {
3687 res.append("->");
3688 res += detail::to_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::second(v));
3689 }
3690 return res;
3691 },
3692 ","));
3693 out.push_back('}');
3694 return out;
3695 }
3696
3697 template <typename C, typename V>
3698 struct has_find {
3699 template <typename CC, typename VV>
3700 static auto test(int) -> decltype(std::declval<CC>().find(std::declval<VV>()), std::true_type());
3701 template <typename, typename>
3702 static auto test(...) -> decltype(std::false_type());
3703
3704 static const auto value = decltype(test<C, V>(0))::value;
3705 using type = std::integral_constant<bool, value>;
3706 };
3707
3708 /// A search function
3709 template <typename T, typename V, enable_if_t<!has_find<T, V>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
3710 auto search(const T& set, const V& val) -> std::pair<bool, decltype(std::begin(detail::smart_deref(set)))> {
3711 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type;
3712 auto& setref = detail::smart_deref(set);
3713 auto it = std::find_if(std::begin(setref), std::end(setref), [&val](decltype(*std::begin(setref)) v) {
3714 return (detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first(v) == val);
3715 });
3716 return {(it != std::end(setref)), it};
3717 }
3718
3719 /// A search function that uses the built in find function
3720 template <typename T, typename V, enable_if_t<has_find<T, V>::value, detail::enabler> = detail::dummy>
3721 auto search(const T& set, const V& val) -> std::pair<bool, decltype(std::begin(detail::smart_deref(set)))> {
3722 auto& setref = detail::smart_deref(set);
3723 auto it = setref.find(val);
3724 return {(it != std::end(setref)), it};
3725 }
3726
3727 /// A search function with a filter function
3728 template <typename T, typename V>
3729 auto search(const T& set, const V& val, const std::function<V(V)>& filter_function)
3730 -> std::pair<bool, decltype(std::begin(detail::smart_deref(set)))> {
3731 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type;
3732 // do the potentially faster first search
3733 auto res = search(set, val);
3734 if ((res.first) || (!(filter_function))) {
3735 return res;
3736 }
3737 // if we haven't found it do the longer linear search with all the element translations
3738 auto& setref = detail::smart_deref(set);
3739 auto it = std::find_if(std::begin(setref), std::end(setref), [&](decltype(*std::begin(setref)) v) {
3740 V a{detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first(v)};
3741 a = filter_function(a);
3742 return (a == val);
3743 });
3744 return {(it != std::end(setref)), it};
3745 }
3746
3747 // the following suggestion was made by Nikita Ofitserov(@himikof)
3748 // done in templates to prevent compiler warnings on negation of unsigned numbers
3749
3750 /// Do a check for overflow on signed numbers
3751 template <typename T>
3752 inline typename std::enable_if<std::is_signed<T>::value, T>::type overflowCheck(const T& a, const T& b) {
3753 if ((a > 0) == (b > 0)) {
3754 return ((std::numeric_limits<T>::max)() / (std::abs)(a) < (std::abs)(b));
3755 }
3756 return ((std::numeric_limits<T>::min)() / (std::abs)(a) > -(std::abs)(b));
3757 }
3758 /// Do a check for overflow on unsigned numbers
3759 template <typename T>
3760 inline typename std::enable_if<!std::is_signed<T>::value, T>::type overflowCheck(const T& a, const T& b) {
3761 return ((std::numeric_limits<T>::max)() / a < b);
3762 }
3763
3764 /// Performs a *= b; if it doesn't cause integer overflow. Returns false otherwise.
3765 template <typename T>
3766 typename std::enable_if<std::is_integral<T>::value, bool>::type checked_multiply(T& a, T b) {
3767 if (a == 0 || b == 0 || a == 1 || b == 1) {
3768 a *= b;
3769 return true;
3770 }
3771 if (a == (std::numeric_limits<T>::min)() || b == (std::numeric_limits<T>::min)()) {
3772 return false;
3773 }
3774 if (overflowCheck(a, b)) {
3775 return false;
3776 }
3777 a *= b;
3778 return true;
3779 }
3780
3781 /// Performs a *= b; if it doesn't equal infinity. Returns false otherwise.
3782 template <typename T>
3783 typename std::enable_if<std::is_floating_point<T>::value, bool>::type checked_multiply(T& a, T b) {
3784 T c = a * b;
3785 if (std::isinf(c) && !std::isinf(a) && !std::isinf(b)) {
3786 return false;
3787 }
3788 a = c;
3789 return true;
3790 }
3791
3792 } // namespace detail
3793 /// Verify items are in a set
3794 class IsMember : public Validator {
3795 public:
3796 using filter_fn_t = std::function<std::string(std::string)>;
3797
3798 /// This allows in-place construction using an initializer list
3799 template <typename T, typename... Args>
3800 IsMember(std::initializer_list<T> values, Args&&... args)
3801 : IsMember(std::vector<T>(values), std::forward<Args>(args)...) {
3802 }
3803
3804 /// This checks to see if an item is in a set (empty function)
3805 template <typename T>
3806 explicit IsMember(T&& set)
3807 : IsMember(std::forward<T>(set), nullptr) {
3808 }
3809
3810 /// This checks to see if an item is in a set: pointer or copy version. You can pass in a function that will filter
3811 /// both sides of the comparison before computing the comparison.
3812 template <typename T, typename F>
3813 explicit IsMember(T set, F filter_function) {
3814 // Get the type of the contained item - requires a container have ::value_type
3815 // if the type does not have first_type and second_type, these are both value_type
3816 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type; // Removes (smart) pointers if needed
3817 using item_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first_type; // Is value_type if not a map
3818
3819 using local_item_t = typename IsMemberType<item_t>::type; // This will convert bad types to good ones
3820 // (const char * to std::string)
3821
3822 // Make a local copy of the filter function, using a std::function if not one already
3823 std::function<local_item_t(local_item_t)> filter_fn = filter_function;
3824
3825 // This is the type name for help, it will take the current version of the set contents
3826 desc_function_ = [set]() {
3827 return detail::generate_set(detail::smart_deref(set));
3828 };
3829
3830 // This is the function that validates
3831 // It stores a copy of the set pointer-like, so shared_ptr will stay alive
3832 func_ = [set, filter_fn](std::string& input) {
3833 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3834 local_item_t b;
3835 if (!lexical_cast(input, b)) {
3836 throw ValidationError(input); // name is added later
3837 }
3838 if (filter_fn) {
3839 b = filter_fn(b);
3840 }
3841 auto res = detail::search(set, b, filter_fn);
3842 if (res.first) {
3843 // Make sure the version in the input string is identical to the one in the set
3844 if (filter_fn) {
3845 input = detail::value_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first(*(res.second)));
3846 }
3847
3848 // Return empty error string (success)
3849 return std::string{};
3850 }
3851
3852 // If you reach this point, the result was not found
3853 return input + " not in " + detail::generate_set(detail::smart_deref(set));
3854 };
3855 }
3856
3857 /// You can pass in as many filter functions as you like, they nest (string only currently)
3858 template <typename T, typename... Args>
3859 IsMember(T&& set, filter_fn_t filter_fn_1, filter_fn_t filter_fn_2, Args&&... other)
3860 : IsMember(
3861 std::forward<T>(set),
3862 [filter_fn_1, filter_fn_2](std::string a) {
3863 return filter_fn_2(filter_fn_1(a));
3864 },
3865 other...) {
3866 }
3867 };
3868
3869 /// definition of the default transformation object
3870 template <typename T>
3871 using TransformPairs = std::vector<std::pair<std::string, T>>;
3872
3873 /// Translate named items to other or a value set
3874 class Transformer : public Validator {
3875 public:
3876 using filter_fn_t = std::function<std::string(std::string)>;
3877
3878 /// This allows in-place construction
3879 template <typename... Args>
3880 Transformer(std::initializer_list<std::pair<std::string, std::string>> values, Args&&... args)
3881 : Transformer(TransformPairs<std::string>(values), std::forward<Args>(args)...) {
3882 }
3883
3884 /// direct map of std::string to std::string
3885 template <typename T>
3886 explicit Transformer(T&& mapping)
3887 : Transformer(std::forward<T>(mapping), nullptr) {
3888 }
3889
3890 /// This checks to see if an item is in a set: pointer or copy version. You can pass in a function that will filter
3891 /// both sides of the comparison before computing the comparison.
3892 template <typename T, typename F>
3893 explicit Transformer(T mapping, F filter_function) {
3894 static_assert(detail::pair_adaptor<typename detail::element_type<T>::type>::value, "mapping must produce value pairs");
3895 // Get the type of the contained item - requires a container have ::value_type
3896 // if the type does not have first_type and second_type, these are both value_type
3897 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type; // Removes (smart) pointers if needed
3898 using item_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first_type; // Is value_type if not a map
3899 using local_item_t = typename IsMemberType<item_t>::type; // Will convert bad types to good ones
3900 // (const char * to std::string)
3901
3902 // Make a local copy of the filter function, using a std::function if not one already
3903 std::function<local_item_t(local_item_t)> filter_fn = filter_function;
3904
3905 // This is the type name for help, it will take the current version of the set contents
3906 desc_function_ = [mapping]() {
3907 return detail::generate_map(detail::smart_deref(mapping));
3908 };
3909
3910 func_ = [mapping, filter_fn](std::string& input) {
3911 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3912 local_item_t b;
3913 if (!lexical_cast(input, b)) {
3914 return std::string();
3915 // there is no possible way we can match anything in the mapping if we can't convert so just return
3916 }
3917 if (filter_fn) {
3918 b = filter_fn(b);
3919 }
3920 auto res = detail::search(mapping, b, filter_fn);
3921 if (res.first) {
3922 input = detail::value_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::second(*res.second));
3923 }
3924 return std::string{};
3925 };
3926 }
3927
3928 /// You can pass in as many filter functions as you like, they nest
3929 template <typename T, typename... Args>
3930 Transformer(T&& mapping, filter_fn_t filter_fn_1, filter_fn_t filter_fn_2, Args&&... other)
3931 : Transformer(
3932 std::forward<T>(mapping),
3933 [filter_fn_1, filter_fn_2](std::string a) {
3934 return filter_fn_2(filter_fn_1(a));
3935 },
3936 other...) {
3937 }
3938 };
3939
3940 /// translate named items to other or a value set
3941 class CheckedTransformer : public Validator {
3942 public:
3943 using filter_fn_t = std::function<std::string(std::string)>;
3944
3945 /// This allows in-place construction
3946 template <typename... Args>
3947 CheckedTransformer(std::initializer_list<std::pair<std::string, std::string>> values, Args&&... args)
3948 : CheckedTransformer(TransformPairs<std::string>(values), std::forward<Args>(args)...) {
3949 }
3950
3951 /// direct map of std::string to std::string
3952 template <typename T>
3953 explicit CheckedTransformer(T mapping)
3954 : CheckedTransformer(std::move(mapping), nullptr) {
3955 }
3956
3957 /// This checks to see if an item is in a set: pointer or copy version. You can pass in a function that will filter
3958 /// both sides of the comparison before computing the comparison.
3959 template <typename T, typename F>
3960 explicit CheckedTransformer(T mapping, F filter_function) {
3961 static_assert(detail::pair_adaptor<typename detail::element_type<T>::type>::value, "mapping must produce value pairs");
3962 // Get the type of the contained item - requires a container have ::value_type
3963 // if the type does not have first_type and second_type, these are both value_type
3964 using element_t = typename detail::element_type<T>::type; // Removes (smart) pointers if needed
3965 using item_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::first_type; // Is value_type if not a map
3966 using local_item_t = typename IsMemberType<item_t>::type; // Will convert bad types to good ones
3967 // (const char * to std::string)
3968 using iteration_type_t = typename detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::value_type; // the type of the object pair
3969
3970 // Make a local copy of the filter function, using a std::function if not one already
3971 std::function<local_item_t(local_item_t)> filter_fn = filter_function;
3972
3973 auto tfunc = [mapping]() {
3974 std::string out("value in ");
3975 out += detail::generate_map(detail::smart_deref(mapping)) + " OR {";
3976 out += detail::join(
3977 detail::smart_deref(mapping),
3978 [](const iteration_type_t& v) {
3979 return detail::to_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::second(v));
3980 },
3981 ",");
3982 out.push_back('}');
3983 return out;
3984 };
3985
3986 desc_function_ = tfunc;
3987
3988 func_ = [mapping, tfunc, filter_fn](std::string& input) {
3989 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
3990 local_item_t b;
3991 bool converted = lexical_cast(input, b);
3992 if (converted) {
3993 if (filter_fn) {
3994 b = filter_fn(b);
3995 }
3996 auto res = detail::search(mapping, b, filter_fn);
3997 if (res.first) {
3998 input = detail::value_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::second(*res.second));
3999 return std::string{};
4000 }
4001 }
4002 for (const auto& v : detail::smart_deref(mapping)) {
4003 auto output_string = detail::value_string(detail::pair_adaptor<element_t>::second(v));
4004 if (output_string == input) {
4005 return std::string();
4006 }
4007 }
4008
4009 return "Check " + input + " " + tfunc() + " FAILED";
4010 };
4011 }
4012
4013 /// You can pass in as many filter functions as you like, they nest
4014 template <typename T, typename... Args>
4015 CheckedTransformer(T&& mapping, filter_fn_t filter_fn_1, filter_fn_t filter_fn_2, Args&&... other)
4016 : CheckedTransformer(
4017 std::forward<T>(mapping),
4018 [filter_fn_1, filter_fn_2](std::string a) {
4019 return filter_fn_2(filter_fn_1(a));
4020 },
4021 other...) {
4022 }
4023 };
4024
4025 /// Helper function to allow ignore_case to be passed to IsMember or Transform
4026 inline std::string ignore_case(std::string item) {
4027 return detail::to_lower(item);
4028 }
4029
4030 /// Helper function to allow ignore_underscore to be passed to IsMember or Transform
4031 inline std::string ignore_underscore(std::string item) {
4032 return detail::remove_underscore(item);
4033 }
4034
4035 /// Helper function to allow checks to ignore spaces to be passed to IsMember or Transform
4036 inline std::string ignore_space(std::string item) {
4037 item.erase(std::remove(std::begin(item), std::end(item), ' '), std::end(item));
4038 item.erase(std::remove(std::begin(item), std::end(item), '\t'), std::end(item));
4039 return item;
4040 }
4041
4042 /// Multiply a number by a factor using given mapping.
4043 /// Can be used to write transforms for SIZE or DURATION inputs.
4044 ///
4045 /// Example:
4046 /// With mapping = `{"b"->1, "kb"->1024, "mb"->1024*1024}`
4047 /// one can recognize inputs like "100", "12kb", "100 MB",
4048 /// that will be automatically transformed to 100, 14448, 104857600.
4049 ///
4050 /// Output number type matches the type in the provided mapping.
4051 /// Therefore, if it is required to interpret real inputs like "0.42 s",
4052 /// the mapping should be of a type <string, float> or <string, double>.
4053 class AsNumberWithUnit : public Validator {
4054 public:
4055 /// Adjust AsNumberWithUnit behavior.
4056 /// CASE_SENSITIVE/CASE_INSENSITIVE controls how units are matched.
4057 /// UNIT_OPTIONAL/UNIT_REQUIRED throws ValidationError
4058 /// if UNIT_REQUIRED is set and unit literal is not found.
4059 enum Options {
4060 CASE_SENSITIVE = 0,
4061 CASE_INSENSITIVE = 1,
4062 UNIT_OPTIONAL = 0,
4063 UNIT_REQUIRED = 2,
4064 DEFAULT = CASE_INSENSITIVE | UNIT_OPTIONAL
4065 };
4066
4067 template <typename Number>
4068 explicit AsNumberWithUnit(std::map<std::string, Number> mapping, Options opts = DEFAULT, const std::string& unit_name = "UNIT") {
4069 description(generate_description<Number>(unit_name, opts));
4070 validate_mapping(mapping, opts);
4071
4072 // transform function
4073 func_ = [mapping, opts](std::string& input) -> std::string {
4074 Number num{};
4075
4076 detail::rtrim(input);
4077 if (input.empty()) {
4078 throw ValidationError("Input is empty");
4079 }
4080
4081 // Find split position between number and prefix
4082 auto unit_begin = input.end();
4083 while (unit_begin > input.begin() && std::isalpha(*(unit_begin - 1), std::locale())) {
4084 --unit_begin;
4085 }
4086
4087 std::string unit{unit_begin, input.end()};
4088 input.resize(static_cast<std::size_t>(std::distance(input.begin(), unit_begin)));
4089 detail::trim(input);
4090
4091 if (opts & UNIT_REQUIRED && unit.empty()) {
4092 throw ValidationError("Missing mandatory unit");
4093 }
4094 if (opts & CASE_INSENSITIVE) {
4095 unit = detail::to_lower(unit);
4096 }
4097 if (unit.empty()) {
4098 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
4099 if (!lexical_cast(input, num)) {
4100 throw ValidationError(std::string("Value ") + input + " could not be converted to " + detail::type_name<Number>());
4101 }
4102 // No need to modify input if no unit passed
4103 return {};
4104 }
4105
4106 // find corresponding factor
4107 auto it = mapping.find(unit);
4108 if (it == mapping.end()) {
4109 throw ValidationError(unit +
4110 " unit not recognized. "
4111 "Allowed values: " +
4112 detail::generate_map(mapping, true));
4113 }
4114
4115 if (!input.empty()) {
4116 using CLI::detail::lexical_cast;
4117 bool const converted = lexical_cast(input, num);
4118 if (!converted) {
4119 throw ValidationError(std::string("Value ") + input + " could not be converted to " + detail::type_name<Number>());
4120 }
4121 // perform safe multiplication
4122 bool const ok = detail::checked_multiply(num, it->second);
4123 if (!ok) {
4124 throw ValidationError(detail::to_string(num) + " multiplied by " + unit +
4125 " factor would cause number overflow. Use smaller value.");
4126 }
4127 } else {
4128 num = static_cast<Number>(it->second);
4129 }
4130
4131 input = detail::to_string(num);
4132
4133 return {};
4134 };
4135 }
4136
4137 private:
4138 /// Check that mapping contains valid units.
4139 /// Update mapping for CASE_INSENSITIVE mode.
4140 template <typename Number>
4141 static void validate_mapping(std::map<std::string, Number>& mapping, Options opts) {
4142 for (auto& kv : mapping) {
4143 if (kv.first.empty()) {
4144 throw ValidationError("Unit must not be empty.");
4145 }
4146 if (!detail::isalpha(kv.first)) {
4147 throw ValidationError("Unit must contain only letters.");
4148 }
4149 }
4150
4151 // make all units lowercase if CASE_INSENSITIVE
4152 if (opts & CASE_INSENSITIVE) {
4153 std::map<std::string, Number> lower_mapping;
4154 for (auto& kv : mapping) {
4155 auto s = detail::to_lower(kv.first);
4156 if (lower_mapping.count(s)) {
4157 throw ValidationError(std::string("Several matching lowercase unit representations are found: ") + s);
4158 }
4159 lower_mapping[detail::to_lower(kv.first)] = kv.second;
4160 }
4161 mapping = std::move(lower_mapping);
4162 }
4163 }
4164
4165 /// Generate description like this: NUMBER [UNIT]
4166 template <typename Number>
4167 static std::string generate_description(const std::string& name, Options opts) {
4168 std::stringstream out;
4169 out << detail::type_name<Number>() << ' ';
4170 if (opts & UNIT_REQUIRED) {
4171 out << name;
4172 } else {
4173 out << '[' << name << ']';
4174 }
4175 return out.str();
4176 }
4177 };
4178
4179 inline AsNumberWithUnit::Options operator|(const AsNumberWithUnit::Options& a, const AsNumberWithUnit::Options& b) {
4180 return static_cast<AsNumberWithUnit::Options>(static_cast<int>(a) | static_cast<int>(b));
4181 }
4182
4183 /// Converts a human-readable size string (with unit literal) to uin64_t size.
4184 /// Example:
4185 /// "100" => 100
4186 /// "1 b" => 100
4187 /// "10Kb" => 10240 // you can configure this to be interpreted as kilobyte (*1000) or kibibyte (*1024)
4188 /// "10 KB" => 10240
4189 /// "10 kb" => 10240
4190 /// "10 kib" => 10240 // *i, *ib are always interpreted as *bibyte (*1024)
4191 /// "10kb" => 10240
4192 /// "2 MB" => 2097152
4193 /// "2 EiB" => 2^61 // Units up to exibyte are supported
4194 class AsSizeValue : public AsNumberWithUnit {
4195 public:
4196 using result_t = std::uint64_t;
4197
4198 /// If kb_is_1000 is true,
4199 /// interpret 'kb', 'k' as 1000 and 'kib', 'ki' as 1024
4200 /// (same applies to higher order units as well).
4201 /// Otherwise, interpret all literals as factors of 1024.
4202 /// The first option is formally correct, but
4203 /// the second interpretation is more wide-spread
4204 /// (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_prefix).
4205 explicit AsSizeValue(bool kb_is_1000);
4206
4207 private:
4208 /// Get <size unit, factor> mapping
4209 static std::map<std::string, result_t> init_mapping(bool kb_is_1000);
4210
4211 /// Cache calculated mapping
4212 static std::map<std::string, result_t> get_mapping(bool kb_is_1000);
4213 };
4214
4215 namespace detail {
4216 /// Split a string into a program name and command line arguments
4217 /// the string is assumed to contain a file name followed by other arguments
4218 /// the return value contains is a pair with the first argument containing the program name and the second
4219 /// everything else.
4220 CLI11_INLINE std::pair<std::string, std::string> split_program_name(std::string commandline);
4221
4222 } // namespace detail
4223 /// @}
4224
4225 CLI11_INLINE std::string Validator::operator()(std::string& str) const {
4226 std::string retstring;
4227 if (active_) {
4228 if (non_modifying_) {
4229 std::string value = str;
4230 retstring = func_(value);
4231 } else {
4232 retstring = func_(str);
4233 }
4234 }
4235 return retstring;
4236 }
4237
4238 CLI11_NODISCARD CLI11_INLINE Validator Validator::description(std::string validator_desc) const {
4239 Validator newval(*this);
4240 newval.desc_function_ = [validator_desc]() {
4241 return validator_desc;
4242 };
4243 return newval;
4244 }
4245
4246 CLI11_INLINE Validator Validator::operator&(const Validator& other) const {
4247 Validator newval;
4248
4249 newval._merge_description(*this, other, " AND ");
4250
4251 // Give references (will make a copy in lambda function)
4252 const std::function<std::string(std::string & filename)>& f1 = func_;
4253 const std::function<std::string(std::string & filename)>& f2 = other.func_;
4254
4255 newval.func_ = [f1, f2](std::string& input) {
4256 std::string const s1 = f1(input);
4257 std::string const s2 = f2(input);
4258 if (!s1.empty() && !s2.empty())
4259 return std::string("(") + s1 + ") AND (" + s2 + ")";
4260 return s1 + s2;
4261 };
4262
4263 newval.active_ = active_ && other.active_;
4264 newval.application_index_ = application_index_;
4265 return newval;
4266 }
4267
4268 CLI11_INLINE Validator Validator::operator|(const Validator& other) const {
4269 Validator newval;
4270
